Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Stable isotope investigation of Fe oxide reactivity and natural isotope fractionation
Award.AbstractNarration:
Iron is well known to change its oxidation state, where, for example, iron metal (Fe0) rapidly oxidizes to ?rust? in the form of Fe3+ oxides and hydroxides. The reverse may occur, where, for example, microbial processes may reduce Fe3+ oxide and hydroxide minerals to Fe2+ minerals or aqueous solutions. These changes, termed ?redox? transformations, profoundly affect the reactivity of iron oxide and hydroxide particles, which in turn may dramatically change the behavior of elements such as carbon, nitrogen, and phosphorus through changes in the absorption properties. Redox transformations affect the reactivity of iron oxide and hydroxide minerals, particularly in nanoparticles (defined as particles that have diameters in the nanometer range ? one-billionth of a meter). It is now recognized that nanoparticles are ubiquitous in the environment and represent one of the major means by which chemical reactions occur.

The work supported by this collaborative grant will bring together researchers and students from geology and engineering, applying a unique isotopic approach to understanding the reactivity of nanoparticulate iron oxides and hydroxides. By studying the spectral properties and relative abundance of the different isotopes of Fe (54Fe, 56Fe, and 57Fe), this work will provide a fingerprint for changes in chemical reactivity of the minerals goethite and magnetite, two very common iron minerals in the environment. The work will study the impact of particle size and chemical composition on particle reactivity. These results will in turn have direct application to studies of paleoclimate, environmental remediation, agricultural practices, and water quality.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Iron oxide and hydroxide minerals are nearly ubiquitous in the surface environments of the Earth, and form a key component to biogeochemical cycles. Microbes gain energy from the changes of oxidation state of iron that may be coupled to various metabolisms. This in turn impacts carbon cycling in surface environments. In addition, the chemical reactivity of iron oxide and hydroxide minerals affects sequestration, or release, or environmental contaminants. Looking into the ancient rock record, massive iron oxide and hydroxide deposits supply all of the iron used in modern society, and although the demand for iron continues to increase, the origin of these deposits remains unclear.

 

This grant supported research that explored the formation mechanisms and reactivity of iron oxide and hydroxide minerals through use of isotopic tracers 17O and 57Fe. In addition, the isotopic fractionations among iron oxide and hydroxide minerals and aqueous solutions was studied using variations in the natural isotopic ratios 18O/16O and 56Fe/54Fe, an approach that yields information on Fe bonding, and provides a tracer that can be applied to ancient rock sequences. In addition, some preliminary studies were completed on Si isotope exchange and fractionation, using a 29Si tracer, as well as variations in 30Si/28Si ratios, in iron-silica gels.

 

Important findings from the work include the discovery that electron transfer between reduced [Fe(II)] and oxidized [Fe(III)] iron will catalyze atom (isotopic) exchange, demonstrating that iron oxide and hydroxide particles are not the inert minerals once thought, but highly reactive components in the environment. In addition, it was found that oxygen and iron atom exchange is not the same, where iron exchanges much more extensively than oxygen in mineral-fluid systems, reflecting the distinct bonding properties of these elements and the movement of electrons for iron species. Some preliminary studies were also completed on the exchange of Si atoms in iron-silica gels, a species that was likely to have been the major early precipitate in the Precambrian oceans. Additional studies of the natural isotopic fractionations in iron oxide and hydroxide minerals supported by this study documented distinct signatures for different minerals, which in turn allowed interpretation of the origin of ancient iron deposits; it was found that the isotopic fingerprint of these economically important deposits requires a major role for iron-respiring bacteria when they formed 2 to 3 billion years ago. Such a finding affects our search for additional deposits, and informs us about the evolution of life on the early Earth.
